question: Hey, what's the rush? C'mon, walk me a couple of blocks.
answer: Jim, I've got to go. I'm already late

question: Listen, Ted... I just want to tell you, when old man Schmidt retires next year, I've got a pretty good feeling they'll kick me upstairs... ...and when they do, I just want you to know I'm takin' you along with me. Y'know, Ted, I mean what I said back there. You did a hell of a job on this and I want you to know I'm turning the whole show over to you.
answer: Wow!

question: I thought you might just like to know that at five-fifteen this afternoon we were officially handed the Fire and Ice account by Revlon.
answer: Ted, I'm leaving you.

question: That represents a gross billing in excess of two million  What?!
answer: Here are my keys. I won't be needing them any more.

question: I'm sorry I'm late, all right? I'm sorry I didn't call  I was busy making a living.
answer: My American Express... My Bloomingdale's Credit Card... My check book

question: Okay, okay... What is it this time? What did I do now?...
answer: I took two thousand out of the savings account. That was what I had in the bank when we got married.

question: Joanna, whatever it is, believe me, I'm sorry.
answer: Here are the slips for the laundry and the cleaning. They'll be ready on Saturday.

question: Now listen, before you do something you'll really regret you'd better stop and think -
answer: I've paid the rent, the Con-Ed and the phone bill, so you don't have to worry about them. There, that's everything.

question: Look, it's not your fault, okay? It's me. It's my fault  you just married the wrong person.
answer: So we've got problems. Everybody's got problems  that's normal

question: Ted, you're not listening to me. It's over, finished.
answer: I'm listening, Joanna  believe me, I'm listening. My wife is walking out on me after eight years of

question: You just don't get it, do you? I  am  really  and  truly  leaving  you.
answer: I heard you, Joanna. I promise I heard you.

question: No you didn't. You didn't even ask about Billy.
answer: What about Billy?

question: I'm not taking him with me.
answer: What?

question: Ted, I can't... I tried... I really tried but... I just can't hack it anymore...
answer: C'mon, Joanna, you don't mean that. You're a terrific mother

question: I am not! I'm a terrible mother! I'm an awful mother. I yell at him all the time. I have no patience. No... No. He's better off without me. Ted, I've got to go... I've got to go.
answer: Okay, I understand and I promise I won't try and stop you, but you can't just go... Look, come inside and talk... Just for a few minutes.

question: NO!... Please... Please don't make me stay... I swear... If you do, sooner or later... maybe tomorrow, maybe next week... maybe a year from now... I'll go right out the window.
answer: Where are you going?

question: I don't know...
answer: Do you want me to help you get a cab?

question: All right, Thelma, you want to know what's going on? I'll tell you what's going on. I'll tell you exactly what's going on.
answer: Look, Ted, all I

question: I came home tonight. We just got the Fire and Ice account at the agency. Do you know what that means?! Do you understand what that means? It means that it was maybe one of the five best days in my whole life.
answer: Ted, all I wanted to know was where

question: I walk in the house and before I can say "How are you?", "Did you have a nice day?" before I can say anything. Pow she's out the door.
answer: OhmyGod. Didn't she say anything? She must've said something.

question: Yeah, she said it wasn't any use talking anymore.
answer: Ted, don't be so hostile.

question: Hostile? Me? Thelma, I'm not hostile. I am anything but hostile. But if you want to know what I am. I'll tell you what I am. What I am is, I am hurt. I am very hurt. And I just want to know one thing, okay? Just one thing... Why? That's all I want to know... Why?
answer: Ted, Joanna and I used to talk a lot and... well, she told me a lot of... ah, things about the two of you.

question: Things? What kind of things?
answer: I mean... things. Ted, Joanna's very unhappy and

question: Listen, Joanna Kramer's got a goddamn good life. She's got a husband that loves her. She's got a terrific kid. She's got a wonderful home
answer: What d'you know about how Joanna felt? You went off to an office every morning and you'd come dragging home at seven or eight every night and as long as dinner was on the table you thought everything was swell.

question: Did it ever occur to you guys that Joanna Kramer's not the easiest person in the world to live with?! Did it?! For one thing she's always thirty minutes late. You can set your watch by it
answer: So she's late. What's the big deal. That's just a way of saying, "Pay attention to me."

question: Two. She is getting to be a real hermit or recluse or whatever it is you call it. Thelma, do you know where I could be in this business if I had a wife that entertained or went out socially
answer: Oh for shit's sake, Ted, you are the most selfish human being I have ever met. No wonder she said you came first, then Billy, then, if there was anything left over, she got the scraps.

question: Joanna said that? Then how come she never said anything like that to me?
answer: Maybe she didn't feel like she should have to. Maybe she felt like if you'd been paying any real attention to her to start with, maybe you would've noticed.

question: Boy, you guys are really something, y'know? I'd like to know one thing, okay  just one little thing. Did you tell Joanna she should leave me?
answer: No.

question: Y'know something Thelma  you are the typhoid Mary of divorce. I mean it. Joanna and I never had any trouble until you and Charley split up.
answer: Ted, divorce is a terrible thing. I know, I went through it. You've got to believe I did everything I could to get Joanna to stay. But I'll tell you something. You may not want to hear it, but it took a lot of courage for Joanna to do what she just did.

question: I'd like to know what the hell kind of courage it takes to walk out on your husband and your child?
answer: Joanna left Billy? She didn't take him with her? Oh Shit.

question: Huh?... Oh God... What time is it?
answer: The little hand is on the six and the big hand is on the nine. Where is mommy?

question: Oh, Christ... Ah, yeah... you want to know why mom's not here, right? Okay, I'm going to tell you... It's like this. Mommy and daddy had a little argument and mommy decided she wanted to go off by herself for a little while. You know how sometimes you get mad and want to go off and be by yourself? Well, it's like that, okay? Okay. Now how about some breakfast?
answer: When is mommy coming back?

question: It's okay. It's gonna be okay...
answer: When is mommy coming back?

question: Soon. I told you before, very soon.
answer: Will she pick me up after school?

question: No. If I'm not here, you go home with Thelma and Kim.
answer: What if she forgets?

question: I'll call Thelma and remind her, okay? Don't worry.
answer: But what happens if she's on her way to school and she gets runned over by a truck and killed? What happens them?

question: Hey... Look who was out celebrating last night.
answer: Uh, Jim... Can I talk to you?

question: Jesus Christ. That's a real blockbuster. I always figured you guys had it made.
answer: You want to know the real kicker? The real kicker is, for the first time in my life  the first time  I feel like a loser.

question: Listen, don't let it get you down. You're going to be fine.
answer: Me? I've never been better. I mean having my wife walk out on me after seven years of marriage agrees with me just fine.

question: Look, Ted, I'm the oldest whore on the beat, okay? Three marriages, two divorces... You're gonna be okay.
answer: I'm going to be okay. The way I see it, Joanna'll come home, it's just a matter of time.

question: She'll be back... But... just in case... I mean, just on the off chance she doesn't. What are you going to do about the kid?
answer: I don't know, Jim. This whole thing has happened so... Pow  like that.

question: Look, it's none of my business, so you can tell me to butt out, okay? But if you want my advice, you'll send Billy away to stay with relatives for a while. Just until you get yourself straightened out.
answer: I don't know, Jim...

question: Ted, this may sound a little rough, but we've just landed the biggest account in the history of this agency, right? And now it's up to us  that's you and me  to deliver the goods. Ted, you're my main man, and if I can't depend on you a hundred and ten percent, twenty-four hours a day, because you're worried about a kid with a runny nose
answer: Jim, I appreciate what you're saying. I mean it, but I really think Joanna's coming back.

question: It's okay... It's okay. We'll talk about it some other time.
answer: Oh, God... OhmyGod... What are you going to do?

question: I don't know, Thel... This whole thing has happened so... Pow, like that.
answer: I mean, what are you going to do about Billy?

question: I'm gonna keep him, why?
answer: Look, this is nothing personal, but I don't think you can do it.

question: Thelma, I've lost my wife, I'm not losing my child.
answer: All right... Okay... But let's get something straight, right now. I mean, I'm sorry about what happened between you and Joanna, but it's not my problem, understand?

question: I'm not going to have you calling every fifteen minutes just because you can't find a hot water bottle, understand? I've got enough trouble raising my own kid. I don't need another one. Got it?
answer: Got it.

question: You're on your own, understand?
answer: I understand.

question: You're sure?
answer: I'm sure.

question: Mrs. Kline, I'm sorry I'm late, but
answer: You're late.

question: I'm sorry, pal, but I had a meeting and
answer: Goodbye. Bye. I was waiting a long time.

question: It wasn't so long, I'm only... ...twenty minutes late.
answer: All the other mothers got here a long time ago...

question: How was school today?
answer: Okay... Same as usual...

question: Billy, don't eat with your fingers.
answer: Sorry.

question: Well, I see the Yankees finally won a game.
answer: Mom, I mean dad?

question: Yeah?
answer: Can I be excused? I'm not hungry. I think I'll go to bed.

question: Sure. Too much birthday cake, right?
answer: I guess...

question: Mrs. Willewska, could you start on Monday?
answer: Mom, I mean dad...

question: Uh huh...
answer: That's not the right soap. We use the kind in the green and yellow box.

question: C'mon, there's not much difference
answer: We use the green and yellow. The pink stuff.

question: What? I've got a lot more than twenty minutes to kill. Three months. How can you tell?
answer: The sprinkler area. Other children are running around, but there is no sign of Billy.

question: Billy?
answer: Another area of the playground. Billy is nowhere in sight.

question: Billy?
answer: Looking in another direction. Nothing.

question: Billy?!
answer: There in the distance is Billy Kramer, running as hard as he can away from Ted.

question: Greatest.
answer: Greatest...

question: Show.
answer: Show...

question: On earth.
answer: On earth.

question: Mr. Kramer, I just wanted to tell you what a wonderful boy your son is.
answer: I don't know... I've been worried... I mean, with what he's been through and everything. I

question: No... No... Billy is doing just fine.
answer: Well, you know it's not easy raising a kid on your own and I thought if we could get together and, uh, discuss

question: Mr. O'Connor called. There's a meeting with the Revlon people in the board room and you're fifteen minutes late.
answer: I know... I know.

question: Mr. Schmidt can't have the figures on the television buy until Monday.
answer: No. Uh, uh. Tell him I asked for it Friday. I want it Friday. Period.

question: Mr. Lombardo from packaging wants to meet on Friday.
answer: Fine.

question: And Mrs. Kelsey called to ask if Billy can come to Stephanie's birthday party on Tuesday.
answer: Yes. Remind me to pick up a "Crying Chrissie" doll at lunch on Tuesday.

question: Yes.
answer: Yes, what?

question: Yes, I'll have dinner with you. Kramer, I've got to go. I've got an eight o'clock closing tomorrow down on Centre Street.
answer: Mmmmnph... I'll get you a cab...

question: Do you? So what's your problem? You ever think about getting married again?
answer: No, not really... I guess it's different if you don't have children, but... I dunno, even if Charley and I don't live together, even if we're sleeping with other people, even if Charley was to marry again... He'd still be my husband. That stuff about "Till death do you part?" That's really true.

question: How many onions does it say to use?
answer: Three. And add some basil.

question: D'you think you and Charley'll ever get back together again?
answer: No. I don't think so.

question: C'mon, Thel. So Charley had a little fling. So what? All in all he was a pretty good husband.
answer: Look, I know this isn't gonna make any sense, okay? I mean forget the logic part... But I keep thinking if Charley really loved me, he wouldn't have let me divorce him.

question: What the hell is this?
answer: Murray had some ideas about the Fire and Ice campaign and he had the art department make up a few roughs... I think they're kind of interesting.

question: I don't. Jim, this isn't anything like what we talked about. It's not even close.
answer: Murray just added a few things, that's all.

question: Now hold it right there, I'm the one that went in and sold Revlon on this idea to start with, remember? You said I was going to be
answer: Yeah? It's for you.

question: Mom, I mean dad...
answer: In a minute...

question: What do you do when an elephant sits on your fence? You get a new fence.
answer: C'mon, Billy. I'm trying to work for God's sake... Goddamnit, can't you watch what you're doing!

question: I'm sorry.
answer: Je-sus Christ! I catch all kind of shit at the office because I'm not pulling my weight because I'm busting my butt trying to be a decent goddamn father and

question: I'm sorry.
answer: That's terrific. That's really terrific, but I notice I'm the one that's cleaning up this  Oh, crap, I'll have to do this one over.

question: I'm sorry.
answer: Look, it's after your bedtime, okay? Just do me a favor and go to bed, okay?

question: How about lunch, Kramer. I'm buying.
answer: Okay, Phyllis, what's up?

question: Kramer... O'Connor's out to get you. He's going to take the Fire and Ice account away from you.
answer: What?!? I don't believe it! That's crazy! Why would Jim do something like that?

question: You want to know why? I'll tell you why... Another scotch and soda for the gentleman. I'll tell you exactly why. Because you're not his buddy anymore. Because he can't count on you to sit around the office every night until eight or nine and shoot the shit with him.
answer: I can't. I've got Billy to take care of.

question: You dope. O'Connor doesn't give a damn about Billy. All he wants is somebody that'll hang around with him every night so he won't have to go home.
answer: I don't believe you.

question: All right. Okay. But tell me something, Kramer. Who do you think is palling around with O'Connor these days?
answer: How should I know?

question: Murray.
answer: So... what's so terrible about that?

question: Oh, for God's sake, Kramer. You have got to be the world's most naive human being. Murray has gone in and changed every single ad you've done on the entire Fire and Ice campaign. Every layout... Every idea... Every single thing, right down the line.
answer: No. No, I don't believe it. Jim O'Connor would never let anything like that happen. He gave me my shot in this business. If it wasn't for Jim O'Connor I'd be  I don't know where I'd be. He's a wonderful man...

question: Kramer, I'm sorry. All I was trying to do was
answer: I don't want to hear another word against him. Not another word. He's a wonderful man... a wonderful man...

question: Salisbury steak.
answer: I hate it.

question: You don't hate it. We had Salisbury steak last week and you liked it fine.
answer: No I didn't. I hate the brown stuff. It's gross.

question: All it is is onions and gravy.
answer: I'm allergic to onions.

question: You are not allergic of onions. You've had them lots of times.
answer: I want a pizza.

question: No. This is fine. Just take a bite, you'll like it fine.
answer: I think I'm going to throw up.

question: Oh, for God's sake... Here. There, okay? Now that's just plain old hamburger.
answer: Some of the brown stuff is still there.

question: Then eat around it.
answer: No.

question: Now listen to me, young man. Do you know what I had to go through to put this goddamn food on the goddamn table?
answer: I don't care. I hate it. I want pizza.

question: Not on your life. That's it. I've had it with crap around this house. From now on, no more pizza! Get it? Starting right now you can eat real food like a normal human being!
answer: No!

question: Goddamnit! Go to your room!
answer: Owwww... You're hurting me... You're hurting me... I hate you... I hate you...

question: You're no bargain either, pal.
answer: I want my mommy... I want my mommy.. I want my... mm... ommy... I want mmmy... mommy...

question: Daddy?
answer: Yeah?

question: I'm sorry...
answer: That's okay, pal. Go back to sleep. It's very late.

question: Daddy?
answer: Uh huh?

question: Of course I'm not going away. I love you very much. I'll be right here.
answer: That's why mommy left... isn't it? 'Cause I was bad...

question: Oh, Christ... Oh, Christ... No, pal. Your mom loves you very much. The reason she left didn't have anything to do with you. Look, I don't know if this will make any sense to you, okay? But I'll try and explain. You see the reason your mom left was because... Well, I guess it was because I kept trying to make her into a certain kind of person... Make her be the way I thought a wife was supposed to be. Only she wasn't like that. She was... Well, she wasn't like that. And now, when I think about it, I can see she tried very hard to be like I wanted  very hard. And when she couldn't, then she tried to tell me about it. Only I wouldn't listen. I guess I thought that if I was happy, that meant she was happy too. Only she wasn't. The truth is, the only reason she didn't leave a lot sooner was because she loves you so much. Joanna stayed until she couldn't stand me any longer and then she left... But it wasn't you, pal. It wasn't you.
answer: Is mom ever coming back?

question: You mean for good? I don't think so.
answer: Oh...

question: Now go to sleep. It's very late.
answer: Good night.

question: Sleep tight.
answer: Don't let the bedbugs bite.

question: See you in the morning light.
answer: Dad?

question: Yes?
answer: I love you...

question: Thel, you ever hear from Joanna?
answer: Not for a couple of months. The last time I heard from her she was living in San Francisco.

question: California?
answer: Uh, huh... She said she had a good job, was playing a lot of tennis. She wanted to know all about Billy.

question: She ever ask about me?
answer: Uh, huh... Yeah...

question: What d'you tell her?
answer: I told her you're doing a pretty good job.

question: That's good, Billy... That's a brave boy... Now then, how's that? Now we've cleaned it out... There. That wasn't so bad, was it? Now then, you just wait here, Billy. I want to talk to your dad for a minute. Your boy is very lucky, Mr. Kramer. One inch over and it would have caught the eye. But I'm going to have to take some stitches.
answer: How many?

question: Ten. Because of the position of the wound and your son's age, I don't think there will be much of a scar. Otherwise I'd call in a plastic surgeon. Now, I'd advise you to wait outside. It'll be eas
answer: No.

question: Mr. Kramer, there's
answer: Fuck you. He's my son. I'm staying with him.

question: He's okay... Thel, can I ask you a favor?
answer: Sure.

question: I don't mean a little favor. I mean a big F favor. Thelma, if I die
answer: What?

question: I didn't say I'm going to die, but if I should
answer: Don't say that! I don't want to hear you say that!

question: Thel, listen to me. If, on the million to one shot that I should  That anything should happen to me. Would you take care of Billy?
answer: Me?! You want me to take care of Billy?!

question: Hello, Ted. You look well.
answer: So do you. Thanks, Gino.

question: How's the new job?
answer: Fine. Look at us, Joanna. Just like any old married couple having dinner. Who would believe it.

question: He's great... except... ...Except he had... he fell and he cut his face. He... He has a scar, Joanna, from about here to here. I can't help but feel somehow... it's my fault. I keep thinking I could've done something  stopped it...
answer: You can't tell it from a distance, Ted.

question: What?
answer: I've seen him.

question: You have?
answer: A few times. Sometimes I sit in that coffee shop across the street and watch when you take him to school.

question: He looks like a terrific kid.
answer: He is... You sat in that coffee shop across from school

question: Watching my son... Ted, I've been living in New York for the past two months.
answer: You've been living here, in the city?

question: Ted... The reason I wanted to see you... I want Billy back.
answer: You want what?!

question: I want my son. I'm through sitting in coffee shops looking at him from across the street. I want my son.
answer: Are you out of your mind?! You're the one that walked out on him, remember?

question: Ted, listen to me... You and I, we had a really crappy marriage  Look, don't get so defensive, okay? It was probably as much my fault as it was yours... Anyway when I left I was really screwed up
answer: Joanna, I don't give a

question: Ted, all my life I'd either been somebody's daughter or somebody's wife, or somebody else's mother. Then all of a sudden, I was a thirty- two-year-old, highly neurotic woman who had just walked out on her husband and child. I went to California because that was about as far away as I could get. Only... I guess it wasn't far enough. So I started going to a shrink. Ted, I've had time to think. I've been through some changes. I've learned a lot about myself.
answer: Such as? Come on, Joanna, what did you learn? I'd really like to know. One thing, okay? Just tell me one goddam thing you've learned.

question: Look, she walked out on her own child, right? That's desertion, right? Mr. Shaunessy, I'm telling you it's an open and shut case.
answer: First, there's no such thing as an open and shut case. Especially where custody is involved. Got it? Second, the burden is on us to prove your ex-wife is an unfit mother. That means I'm going to have to play rough and, if I play rough, you can bet they will too. Can you take that, Mr. Kramer? Third, it'll cost you five thousand dollars. That's if we win. If we lose, you could end up having to pay your wife's court costs as well.

question: Fine.
answer: Good. You've hired yourself a hell of a lawyer, Mr. Kramer. How old is the child?

question: Six.
answer: That's tough. In most cases involving a child that young, the court tends to side with the mother.

question: Ummm, hmmm... umm, hmmm... Well, this looks very good.. Of course ...you understand this is the worst time of the year to look for a job.
answer: What?! What do you mean, I don't understand.

question: Mr. Kramer, nobody even thinks about leaving their job until after they get their Christmas bonus.
answer: Look, you don't understand. I need a job. I've got a kid and

question: Uh, huh?
answer: Ted? They've set the court date. I just heard today... It's... January sixth.

question: Oh, Christ.. .John, there's some- thing I ought to tell you. My... ah, situation has... changed. I lost my job. John?
answer: Ted, I won't lie to you, we don't have a hope in hell of winning a custody hearing if you're out of work.

question: Good Christ, Joanna, just get the hell out of my life.
answer: Ted? Are you there?

question: Yeah.
answer: Any prospects?

question: Don't worry. I plan to have something within twenty-four hours, John.
answer: How the hell are you going to do that?

question: I need a job, now.
answer: No... No... No... There might be something at J. Walter Thompson. But... ...I don't think they're really serious. The position's been open for two months and... They may just be on a fishing expedition. I'm sure you'll be much happier if you wait until after the first

question: Call up the people at J. Walter Thompson. Set up an appointment at four.
answer: Mis-ter Kramer, it's... ...almost four now. It's the Friday before Christmas. Nobody is going to want to

question: Either you call and set up the appointment, or I'll call. And if I call, you lose the commission.
answer: My, we are a hot shot aren't we?

question: Well, Mr. Kramer, I must say this has been very impressive. I'd like to think about it and get back to you.
answer: Mr. Ackerman, is there anyone else that I should see before you come to a decision.

question: Mr. Spencer, our Advertising Director.
answer: Could I see him right away?

question: I'm sorry, but he's leaving this evening for a two-week vacation. I'll set up something the moment he gets back.
answer: I'd like to see him now  before he leaves.

question: Mr. Kramer, I don't think
answer: I want this position very much.

question: So, naturally, you assume that since Joanna left, that would be a compelling point against her, right?
answer: Right.

question: But it doesn't work that way. A major decision was handed down by the Appellate Court in 1969  in the case of Haskins vs. Haskins.
answer: Kramer

question: Now in Haskins vs. Haskins the court ruled in favor of the mother, thus establishing a precedent for awarding the child to the mother even though she previously abandoned the baby.
answer: Kramer... There's something I ought to tell you.

question: Yeah?
answer: I've been offered a job in Washington with H.E.W.

question: Mr. Kramer?
answer: Yes?

question: I'm Dr. Alvarez, Judge Atkins asked me to look in on your son and prepare an evaluation sheet.
answer: Oh, yes. Won't you come in.

question: Where is the child?
answer: He's in his room, playing.

question: Good. I'll see him in there. Mr. Kramer, do you ever have sex in here with anyone?
answer: Doctor, I attempt to conduct my social life discreetly. At the moment I am seeing no one.

question: Does that distress you?
answer: Not particularly.

question: What does?
answer: The prospect of losing my child.

question: Very well, I'd like to see him if I may.
answer: Billy. This is Dr. Alvarez. She would like to talk to you.

question: What do you have here, Billy?
answer: Detroit.

question: Have you ever been to Detroit?
answer: No. But I've been to Brooklyn.

question: I see you have people there. What are their names?
answer: That's Kim... and this one's Thelma and that's Mrs. Willewska and this is daddy and that's Batman and over there is Robin.

question: What about your mommy?
answer: Oh, sure. Here, this can be mommy.

question: Sure.
answer: What do you like best about her?

question: Lunch in a restaurant.
answer: What do you like best about your daddy?

question: Playing.
answer: Tell me, does your daddy ever hit you?

question: Sure. Lots of times.
answer: When does he hit you?

question: He hits me on the planet Kriptarium, when I steal the buried treasure from the famous peanut butter factory.
answer: In real life when does he hit you?

question: Wow!
answer: You like it?

question: Wow! Is this really where you work? Is this really your desk?
answer: Yep.

question: Is that really your chair?
answer: Uh huh...

question: Wow! That's neat. Can I sit in it?
answer: Sure.

question: Did mommy ever see this?
answer: No, she never did.

question: Are you going to get remarried?
answer: I don't know. I hadn't thought much about it.

question: Are you going to remarried Phyllis?
answer: No.

question: Will you and mommy get remarried?
answer: No, son. Daddy and mommy will never get remarried.

question: Now then, Mrs. Kramer, would you tell the court how long you were married?
answer: Six years.

question: And would you describe those years as happy?
answer: The first couple, yes, but after that it became increasingly difficult.

question: Mrs. Kramer, did you ever work in a job while you were married to your ex-husband?
answer: No, I did not.

question: Did you wish to?
answer: Yes. I tried to talk to Ted  my ex- husband  about it, but he wouldn't listen. He refuses to discuss it in any serious way. I remember one time he said I probably couldn't get a job that would pay enough to hire a baby-sitter for Billy.

question: Tell me, Mrs. Kramer, are you employed at the present time?
answer: Yes, I work for Jantzen as a sportswear designer.

question: And what is your present salary?
answer: I make thirty-one thousand dollars a year.

question: Mrs. Kramer, do you love your child?
answer: Yes. Very much.

question: And yet you chose to leave him?
answer: Yes... Look, during the last five years we were married, I had... I was getting more and more... unhappy, more and more frustrated. I needed to talk to somebody. I needed to find out if it was me, if I was going crazy or what. But every time I turned to Ted  my ex-husband, he couldn't handle it. He became very... I don't know, very threatened. I mean, whenever I would bring up anything he would act like it was some kind of personal attack. Anyway, we became more and more separate... more and more isolated from one another. Finally, I had no other choice, I had to leave. And because of my ex- husband's attitude  his unwillingness to deal with my feelings, I had come to have almost no self-esteem... At the time I left, I sincerely believed that there was something wrong with me  that my son would be better off without me. It was only when I got to California and started into therapy I began to realize I wasn't a terrible person. And that just because I needed some creative and emotional outlet other than my child, that didn't make me unfit to be a mother.

question: Your honor, I would like to place in evidence a report on Mrs. Kramer's therapy by her therapist, Dr. Elinore Freedman of La Jolla, California. Mr. Kramer, why did you set up residence in New York?
answer: Because my son is here. And his father is here. As a mother, I don't want my child to be separated from his father.

question: Mrs. Kramer, can you tell the court why you are asking for custody?
answer: Because he's my child... Because I love him. I know I left my son, I know that's a terrible thing to do. Believe me, I have to live with that every day of my life. But just because I'm a woman, don't I have a right to the same hopes and dreams as a man? Don't I have a right to a life of my own? Is that so awful? Is my pain any less just because I'm a woman? Are my feelings any cheaper? I left my child  I know there is no excuse for that. But since then, I have gotten help. I have worked hard to become a whole human being. I don't think I should be punished for that. I don't think my son should be punished for that. Billy's only six. He needs me. I'm not saying he doesn't need his father, but he needs me more. I'm his mother.

question: Now then, Mrs. Kramer, you said you were married seven years. Is that correct?
answer: Yes.

question: In all that time did your husband ever strike you or abuse you physically in any way.
answer: No.

question: Did your husband strike or physically abuse his child in any way?
answer: No.

question: Would you describe your husband as an alcoholic?
answer: No.

question: A heavy drinker?
answer: No.

question: Was he unfaithful?
answer: No.

question: Did he ever fail to provide for you?
answer: No.

question: I'll ask it another way. What was the longest personal relationship you have had in your life  other than parents and girlfriends?
answer: Ah... I guess I'd have to say... with my child.

question: Whom you've seen twice in a year? Mrs. Kramer, your ex-husband, wasn't he the longest personal relationship in your life?
answer: I suppose...

question: Would you speak up, Mrs. Kramer? I couldn't hear you.
answer: Yes.

question: How long was that?
answer: We were married two years before the baby. And then four very difficult years.

question: Now then, Mr. O'Connor, how long did Ted Kramer work for you?
answer: Eight, almost nine years.

question: And did you have a close personal relationship?
answer: Yes...

question: And how did you find his work?
answer: It was good. He was a hard worker, a lot of drive, a real hustler.

question: And yet you fired him.
answer: Ted was a good worker. But, ah... after his wife left him and he was taking care of the kid on his own, things started to change. Look, I know he had problems, I understand that. I've got problems, everybody's got problems. But I've got a shop to run, I can't let that kind of thing get in the way... I guess I felt that Ted was letting his duties at home interfere with his responsibilities in the office.

question: Mom  I mean, dad?
answer: Uh, huh?

question: What did you do when you were little?
answer: I guess about the same kind of things you do.

question: Did you watch "I Dream of Jeannie?"
answer: Uh, uh... We didn't have television then.

question: Nope. It hadn't been invented yet.
answer: Was there apple juice when you were little?

question: Yeah, there was apple juice.
answer: Was there Burger King?

question: Uh, uh. There was no such a thing as Burger King.
answer: What else wasn't there?

question: Mrs. Phillips, how long have you known Ted Kramer?
answer: Six years. Ever since Ted and Joanna moved into the building.

question: How often do you see Mr. Kramer and his son?
answer: Charley, my husband, and I are... divorced and Kim, that's our daughter is about Billy's age and the children play together a lot. So, I guess we see each three or four times a week.

question: Can you describe the relationship between Mr. Kramer and his son?
answer: It's beautiful. It's just beautiful. They have a beautiful relationship.

question: Mr. Kramer, isn't it true that you were fired from your last job not more than six weeks ago?
answer: Technically, the agency lost a big account and seventy four people were let go. I was one of them.

question: You were fired, correct?
answer: Yes, but I'm with J. Walter Thompson now. I don't think that will happen again.

question: While the child was in the care of the witness, he cut his face badly and is now scarred.
answer: Are you introducing the question of negligence here, counselor?

question: Yes, your honor.
answer: I see. Well, you'll have to do better than that. Do you have any affidavits to support negligence?

question: I do not, your honor, however
answer: This is an isolated incident, counselor, unless you can prove otherwise.

question: Does the witness deny the injury took place?
answer: No, counselor, I'm going to over- rule you on this line of questioning.

question: You heard anything yet?
answer: Any day.

question: Ted.
answer: Uh, huh...

question: Ah, Charley and I are... Well, we're thinking about... I mean, actually we're sort of talking about maybe getting back together.
answer: You and Charley? Really? Hey, that's terrific.

question: Oh, Christ!
answer: The judge went for motherhood straight down the line.

question: I lost him? I lost him?
answer: I can't tell you how sorry I am.

question: Oh, no..
answer: Ordered, adjudged and decreed that the petitioner be awarded custody of the minor child, effective Monday the 23rd of January. That the respondent pay for the maintenance and support of said child, four hundred dollars each month. That the father shall have the following rights of visitation

question: What if I fight it?
answer: We can appeal, but I can't guarantee anything.

question: I'll take my chances.
answer: It's going to cost.

question: Don't worry. I'll get the money.
answer: I've got to tell you something, Ted. This time it'll be Billy that pays. This time I'll have to put him on the stand.

question: Oh, Christ no... I can't do that. I just... can't... Excuse me... I'm sorry... I just...
answer: Ted!... It's me... Ted?...

question: Please go away, Thel... I... I just have to be by myself for a little while...
answer: Ted, I just heard...

question: Please, Thel...
answer: I'm so... sorry... Oh, Ted, I'm so sorry...

question: His best stories have been Babar and Winnie the Pooh up to now, with Batman moving up. His housekeeper has been Etta Willewska and she is the main reason for the note. She is a loving woman, conscientious, very concerned about Billy and more important, Billy cares about her. I urge you to retain her. Her number is 722-8099, and I think she will take the job if it is offered. I'm sure other things will come up. Ask me what you need to and I guess eventually we'll talk... That's all I can think of, except to repeat what I said before, he's a terrific kid. I'm grateful for the time we've had together and I feel I am a better man because of my son... Ted. Billy, sometimes when a mother and a father are divorced, there's a discussion about who the child should live with, the mother or the father. Now there is a man who is very wise. He's called a judge. And a judge has a lot of experience with divorces and he decides who it would be best for the child to live with.
answer: Why does he decide?

question: Because... Well, that's what he does. He's a very powerful man.
answer: Like a principal?

question: Bigger than a principal. The judge sits in robes in a big chair... The judge has thought a lot about us, about you and me and your mom, and he has decided... ...he has decided that it would be best for you to live with your mom Joanna in her apartment. And I'm very lucky. Because even though you'll live with your mom Joanna I'll get to see you once a week for dinner and a couple of weekends a month.
answer: I don't understand, daddy.

question: What don't you understand, pal?
answer: Where will my bed be, where will I sleep?

question: At your mom's. She'll have a bed for you in your own room.
answer: Where will my toys be?

question: I'll send your toys there and I'm sure you'll get some new ones.
answer: Who will read me my stories?

question: Your mom.
answer: Daddy, what if The Face comes when I'm at mommy's?

question: Your mom knows all about The Face, okay? Don't worry, she'll tell The Face to beat it.
answer: Will you come and say good-night to me every night?

question: Okay, I'm here. Now why did you
answer: Ted, do you love him?

question: Goddamnit, Joanna. What the
answer: Ted, do you love him? I love him too... I don't think I ever knew how much until now. Ted, when we got married it was because I was twenty-seven years old and I thought I should get married and... when I had Billy it was because I thought I should have a baby... and I guess all I did was mess up my life and your life and

question: Joanna, what the hell is
answer: Please... Please don't stop me. This is the hardest thing I've ever had to do..
